comment: The English opening. White takes possession of d5.
Preparing to play 3... d5. Also playable is 2... e5.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e6 3. Nf3 d5 4. d4
comment: This position can also arise from the Queen's gambit as follows: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Nf3.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e6 3. Nf3 d5 4. d4 c5
comment: This variation is called the Semi-Tarrasch Defense.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e6 3. Nf3 d5 4. d4 c5 5. cxd5
comment: If 5... exd5 then Black will end up with an isolated queen pawn.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e6 3. Nf3 d5 4. d4 c5 5. cxd5 Nxd5
comment: The usual next move for White when this game was played was 6. e3

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e6 3. Nf3 d5 4. d4 c5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. e4
comment: Spassky will demonstrate the strength of the pawn center.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e6 3. Nf3 d5 4. d4 c5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. e4 Nxc3 7. bxc3 cxd4 8. cxd4
comment: White now occupies the center. The question is whether he will be able to use it to advantage or spend all his energy protecting it.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e6 3. Nf3 d5 4. d4 c5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. e4 Nxc3 7. bxc3 cxd4 8. cxd4 Bb4+
comment: The side with less space should strive to exchange pieces.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e6 3. Nf3 d5 4. d4 c5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. e4 Nxc3 7. bxc3 cxd4 8. cxd4 Bb4+ 9. Bd2 Bxd2+ 10. Qxd2 O-O 11. Bc4
1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e6 3. Nf3 d5 4. d4 c5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. e4 Nxc3 7. bxc3 cxd4 8. cxd4 Bb4+ 9. Bd2 Bxd2+ 10. Qxd2 O-O 11. Bc4 Nc6
comment: Developing and beginning to put pressure on White's center.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e6 3. Nf3 d5 4. d4 c5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. e4 Nxc3 7. bxc3 cxd4 8. cxd4 Bb4+ 9. Bd2 Bxd2+ 10. Qxd2 O-O 11. Bc4 Nc6 12. O-O b6
comment: The bishop is better placed on b7 then d7.
